subject: Ethics
title: Trolley Problem Variations
description: A short lesson to help you apply Trolley Problem Variations.

hook.text: A trolley is about to kill five people. You can pull a lever to divert itâ€”killing one. Do you pull?

buildup.text: Most people say yes. But now imagine pushing a large man off a bridge to stop the trolley.

discovery.text: Same mathâ€”one dies to save fiveâ€”but most people refuse. The directness of killing changes everything.

twist.text: Philippa Foot and Judith Thomson used these cases to reveal hidden intuitions about harm and intent.

climax.text: The trolley problem isn't about trains. It's about when consequences can override personal rights.

punchline.text: The question isn't what happens. It's what you do.

quiz.question: What does the trolley problem primarily reveal about moral reasoning?
options: People always choose to save the most lives
There's a tension between consequences and how directly we cause harm
Thought experiments have no practical value
